awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Combining elemental and biochemical measures of prey to improve predictions of trophic transfers of nutrients
awd_abstract_narration:
Food webs describe the flow of energy and nutrients through communities and ecosystems. Elements (e.g., carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus) are the most common currency used by ecologists for measuring food web connections and comparing them across different ecosystems. Yet, other measures of diet such as macronutrients (i.e., carbohydrate, lipid, and protein) can also be useful because they provide more information on the quality of biochemical compounds. The overall goal of this work is to develop a framework for studying food webs that combines elements and macronutrients and then to test if this better predicts the amounts and types of nutrients transferred among organisms in food webs than elements alone. This research will focus on insects and other arthropods as they are some of the most diverse and abundant members of terrestrial ecosystems and a major food source for invertebrate and vertebrate predators. Better understanding how food webs function is an important goal for management of agricultural and natural ecosystem. During the course of this work, the project will also advance secondary STEM education by providing high school students and pre-service teachers with authentic research experiences and by training teachers in ways to incorporate research into classroom lesson plans.

This research will test two objectives important for better uniting elemental and macronutrient approaches to studying food webs. First, the project will test the long-held assumption that elements and macronutrients are correlated with each other in diverse arthropods, which preliminary data suggest may not be well-supported. Then, the project will test if a hybrid currency, macronutrient-partitioned elements, is a better predictor of the transfer of nutrients from prey to predator and the transfer of nutrients from arthropod carcasses to soil decomposers than elements alone. This work is intellectually risky because it represents a significant departure from two fields (i.e., ecological stoichiometry and nutritional geometry) that have traditionally measured nutrients differently (i.e., elements versus macronutrients). However, the potential rewards of this work are great as it may unite these parallel and complementary paradigms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
A variety of animals consume arthropods and it is important to understand how different species of arthropods vary in quality for consumers. Several currencies have commonly been used to measure prey quality including: elements (e.g., carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus) and biochemicals (e.g., macronutrients such as carbohydrates, lipid, and protein). Different nutritional currencies are typically used in separate studies and the relationships between them have been unclear, especially for arthropods. In arthropods, some of the elements in their bodies can be found in their exoskeleton, which is largely indigestible to predators. Hence, measures of prey nutrient content that do not account for the amount of exoskeleton in arthropods, which can vary among species, may not be the best predictors of how many nutrients will be consumed by predators feeding on those arthropods.  The goals of this study were to: 1) examine relationships between elements and biochemicals in arthropods, and 2) to examine if elements, biochemicals, or a hybrid measure best explained the transfer of nutrients from arthropod prey to spider consumers and prey decomposition.

 

To examine the relationship between elements and biochemicals in arthropods, we collected a diversity of different arthropod species including many insects and arachnids. We analyzed the nutritional composition of these arthropods in terms of elements and biochemicals, and tested for relationships between these two measures. We found that the nitrogen content of the soft tissues of prey (i.e., metabolizable nitrogen, which is all nitrogen that is not in the exoskeleton) was more closely related to the protein content of prey than was the total nitrogen content of prey, which does not account for how much of the nitrogen is in the prey exoskeleton. We also found relationships between total or metabolizable carbon content and prey energy content; although, the strengths of the relationships were relatively low.

 

In the second objective, we examined whether elements or biochemicals were better predictors of how nutrients are transferred in food webs. In a study of spider assimilation of nutrients when feeding on arthropods, we found that the metabolizable carbon and nitrogen content of an arthropod’s body was a better predictor of how much carbon and nitrogen was consumed by a predator feeding on it than was the total carbon or nitrogen content of that prey. Next, in a study of spider growth, we found that spiders did not grow largest on the highest nitrogen prey. This is likely because the prey that we used, cockroaches, can achieve high nitrogen content by storing nitrogen as uric acid in their bodies and this uric acid may be a lower quality form of nitrogen than protein. Finally, we observed decomposition of arthropod carcasses on soil and found that arthropods with higher exoskeleton content released less CO2, likely because the exoskeleton was slow to decompose.

 

Overall, the results of this study suggest that combining elemental and biochemical approaches may be useful for better understanding the flow of nutrients through arthropod food webs. Total elemental content of arthropods does not distinguish which parts of the arthropod body are metabolizable (i.e., possible to be consumed by predators or to decompose rapidly) versus recalcitrant (i.e., indigestible or slow to decompose). Yet, even basic measures of biochemicals, such as the exoskeleton content of prey can help partition elements into metabolizable and recalcitrant portions to better predict how they will affect the flow of nutrients to predators and decomposition.

 

This grant allowed for training of a postdoctoral research associate who gained valuable experience leading project objectives and mentoring undergraduate students. This grant also provided an opportunity for training four preservice science teachers to conduct scientific experiments using arthropods. In addition to research, each student was mentored in creating a class lesson plan that provided an example of how they could use their research experiences to create inquiry-based learning exercises for K-12 students in the classroom. This research increased the preservice teacher’s knowledge of the process of science and should help them better teach the scientific method to students throughout their careers. Finally, this project created educational opportunities for preschool – 6th grade students. I gave presentations on arthropod behavior, ecology, and diversity to a local preschool, a homeschool cooperative, and a pandemic pod of students.

 


Last Modified: 09/26/2021
Modified by: Shawn M Wilder
